questions.question_text: How would information be found about which Kubernetes cluster and pod are using a given PersistentVolume in vSphere?

choices.C: Using the vSphere Client, go to the Cloud Native Storage view for the datastore
choices.D: By using vmwarectrl get persistentvolumes command
choices.A: Through the file browser in the Datastore view within vCenter
choices.B: By querying the CNS API using the esxcli command

questions.question_text: What provides a declarative, Kubernetes-style API for cluster creation, configuration, and management?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I will go with "A", here's why: 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-4D0D375F-C001-4F1D-AAB1-1789C5577A94.html

A. Tanzu Kubernetes Grid Service - Yes, document says TKG provides an API
B. kubectl - No, this has nothing to do directly with APIs
C. vSphere REST API - No, this is for VSphere VMs and hosts etc
D. Virtual Machine Service - What no

choices.C: A guaranteed class provides high availability for TKC nodes.
choices.B: A best-effort class reserves CPU and Memory resources for TKC nodes.
choices.A: A best-effort class does not provide high availability for TKC nodes.
choices.D: A guaranteed class reserves CPU and Memory resources for TKC nodes.

questions.question_text: Which description accurately characterizes virtual machine class types for Tanzu Kubernetes cluster (TKC) nodes?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
I will go with "D". 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-7351EEFF-4EF0-468F-A19B-6CEA40983D3D.html 

A. A best-effort class does not provide high availability for TKC nodes. - No, it's not about HA
B. A best-effort class reserves CPU and Memory resources for TKC nodes. - No, best-effort does not reserve resources
C. A guaranteed class provides high availability for TKC nodes. - No, it's not about HA
D. A guaranteed class reserves CPU and Memory resources for TKC nodes. - Yes

choices.D: By deploying an external authentication solution
choices.C: By having the Supervisor Cluster poll the TKG cluster periodically to ensure adherence to quotas and permissions
choices.A: By routing quota and permission API calls to vCenter Server via the Supervisor Cluster
choices.B: By ensuring each TKG cluster has a quotas and permissions system built into it natively which enforces all requests

questions.question_text: How are quotas and permissions guaranteed by vSphere with Tanzu for Tanzu Kubernetes (TKG) clusters that are deployed within a namespace?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I'm not sure about this one. I'll go with "B" because it seems reasonable. 

A. By routing quota and permission API calls to vCenter Server via the Supervisor Cluster

I'm not sure... why does this have to be API calls? The whole point of Tanzu is that you can do a lot of administration through vCenter and kubectl. 

B. By ensuring each TKG cluster has a quotas and permissions system built into it natively which enforces all requests

This is true, and I guess the best answer. TKG clusters and namespaces leverage inbuilt quota and permissions systems, and these do enforce all requests. 

C. By having the Supervisor Cluster poll the TKG cluster periodically to ensure adherence to quotas and permissions

No... polling is not the way this is done (and a terrible idea because you can do what you want between polls? Ha...)

D. By deploying an external authentication solution

No, this is certainly handled by TKG, no need for an external one. 

While "A" looks compelling, "B" seems a better answer. I choose that.

choices.E: Physical Network MTU set to 1600 Bytes
choices.B: vCenter Server connected to the workload network
choices.A: Network Interface Cards with Single Root IO Virtualization support (SR-IOV)
choices.D: One workload network designated as the primary workload network

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
They say pick two, and then only pick 1. It's C & D.

Selected Answer: D
Thanks ExamTopics, this question requires two answers but they entered it as a single answer question. This is bad!!!

The answers should be C & D, here's why: 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-7FF30A74-DDDD-4231-AAAE-0A92828B93CD.html

A. Network Interface Cards with Single Root IO Virtualization support (SR-IOV) - Not needed
B. vCenter Server connected to the workload network - No, just the management network
C. Non-overlapping subnets on workload networks - Yes (see doc link)
D. One workload network designated as the primary workload network - Yes (see doc link)
E. Physical Network MTU set to 1600 Bytes - Not needed
